subject: StackOverflowException using XMLEncoder
msgSnippet: Greetings, I am new  to junit and this group.  I wrote a test ( code follows ) using XMLEncoder ( hence JVM = 1.4 ) that bombs w/ StackOverflowException
messageBody:
Greetings, I am new to junit and this group. I wrote a test ( code
follows ) using XMLEncoder ( hence JVM >= 1.4 ) that bombs w/
StackOverflowException everytime. I ran the SAME code in my classes'
main method, w/o junit, and it works fine. I Googled this but couldn't
come up w/ anything. Should I just not to be able to write objects out
as .xml files w/ junit? What did I goof up?

Thanks -Tom.

//My test....

import junit.framework.*;
import java.io.*;
import java.beans.*;

public class BeanerTest extends TestCase
{
public BeanerTest( String name ){ super( name ); }

public void testWrite()
{
String FILENAME = "beanerTest.xml";
Beaner beaner = new Beaner( "eat more beans!" );
try
{
XMLEncoder enc = new XMLEncoder(new BufferedOutputStream( new
FileOutputStream( FILENAME )));
enc.writeObject( beaner );
enc.close();
} catch ( Exception x ){ x.printStackTrace( System.err ); }
System.out.println( "wrote sucessfully" );
File file = new File( FILENAME );
assertTrue( file.exists() );
}

/* JUNIT */

public static Test suite()
{
return new TestSuite( BeanerTest.class );
}

public static void main( String[] args )
{
junit.textui.TestRunner.run( suite() );
}
}

----------------------------------------------|
//the class...

import java.io.*;
import java.beans.*;

public class Beaner implements java.io.Serializable
{

String name;

public Beaner(){}

public Beaner( String s ){ name = s; }

public String getName(){ return name; }
public void setName( String s ){ name =s ; }

/** for testing w/o jUnit -- this code works! */
public static void main( String[] args )
{
String FILENAME = "beanerTest.xml";
Beaner beaner = new Beaner( "yummy beans 3 times a day!" );
try
{
XMLEncoder enc = new XMLEncoder(new BufferedOutputStream( new
FileOutputStream( FILENAME )));
enc.writeObject( beaner );
enc.close();
} catch ( Exception x ){ x.printStackTrace( System.err ); }
File file = new File( FILENAME );
if( file.exists() ){ System.out.println( "wrote successfully" ); }
}
}
